questions.text: The most common manifestation of renal disorders is Uremic features. Which of the following is not life threatening uremic feature?
Match the following renal tubular defect with their presentation:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 1. Type 1 RTA (Distal RTA) → C. Nephrocalcinosis
  • • Explanation: Type 1 RTA is characterized by a defect in the distal renal tubule's ability to secrete hydrogen ions. This leads to persistent acidosis and, crucially, an inability to excrete acid urine, resulting in a relatively alkaline urine pH. The combination of systemic acidosis, hypercalciuria (due to bone buffering and reduced calcium reabsorption), and alkaline urine increases the precipitation of calcium phosphate in the renal tubules, leading to nephrocalcinosis (calcification within the kidney parenchyma) and kidney stones.
  • • 2. Type 2 RTA (Proximal RTA) → D. Fanconi's syndrome
  • • Explanation: Type 2 RTA is caused by a defect in the proximal tubule's ability to reabsorb bicarbonate. This often occurs as part of a more generalized dysfunction of the proximal tubule, known as Fanconi's syndrome. Fanconi's syndrome involves impaired reabsorption of various substances in the proximal tubule, including glucose, amino acids, phosphate, and bicarbonate, leading to their excessive excretion in the urine.
  • • 3. Type 3 RTA → B. Cerebral calcifications
  • • Explanation: Type 3 RTA is an older classification, sometimes used to describe a mixed form of RTA (features of both Type 1 and Type 2) or specific inherited syndromes. A notable syndrome that causes a mixed RTA and is associated with cerebral calcifications (as well as osteopetrosis) is carbonic anhydrase II deficiency. While rare, this specific genetic cause ties an RTA presentation to cerebral calcifications.
  • • 4. Type 4 RTA (Hyperkalemic RTA) → A. Asymptomatic
  • • Explanation: Type 4 RTA is characterized by impaired potassium and acid excretion, typically due to a deficiency in aldosterone or tubular unresponsiveness to aldosterone (hypoaldosteronism). While hyperkalemia can cause serious symptoms (especially cardiac arrhythmias), many patients with mild-to-moderate Type 4 RTA, particularly if managed, can be relatively asymptomatic from their acidosis or hyperkalemia, especially if they don't develop severe complications. In a multiple-choice setting, "asymptomatic" is a plausible non-specific presentation if no more specific hallmark (like hyperkalemia itself) is provided as an option.

questions.text: In Fanconi’s syndrome, following features are present EXCEPT:
Match the following renal tubular defects with their cause/mimics:
Following are the features of Liddle’s syndrome EXCEPT:
The most common Bone disease in CKI
Anemia of advanced renal insufficiency is best treated by EPO injection. The other causes of Anaemia in renal failure include all of the following EXCEPT:
Following parameters indicate “Significant Hematuria” except
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gross hematuria (A) is visible blood in the urine, which is always considered significant and warrants investigation. RBC > 100/hpf on a single occasion (C) also indicates significant hematuria, suggesting a substantial amount of blood loss. "Significant hematuria" is typically defined as 3 or more red blood cells per high-power field (RBC/hpf) in a properly collected urine specimen , often confirmed on multiple occasions to rule out transient or benign causes. Option B, with 3-100 RBC/hpf on three or more occasions , aligns with the definition of persistent microscopic hematuria which still requires investigation, but the question asks for what doesn't indicate "significant hematuria" when other options are clearly significant. The nuance here is that while 3-100 RBC/hpf can be significant, the specific wording of "except" suggests that among the choices, this range, even on multiple occasions, might be less immediately alarming than gross hematuria or extremely high RBC counts on a single occasion, which often trigger more urgent workups. However, in many clinical guidelines, microscopic hematuria (defined as >= 3 RBC/hpf) is considered significant, especially if persistent.
  • • Gross hematuria (A) is visible blood in the urine, which is always considered significant and warrants investigation.
  • • Gross hematuria (A)
  • • RBC > 100/hpf on a single occasion (C) also indicates significant hematuria, suggesting a substantial amount of blood loss.
  • • RBC > 100/hpf on a single occasion (C)
  • • "Significant hematuria" is typically defined as 3 or more red blood cells per high-power field (RBC/hpf) in a properly collected urine specimen , often confirmed on multiple occasions to rule out transient or benign causes. Option B, with 3-100 RBC/hpf on three or more occasions , aligns with the definition of persistent microscopic hematuria which still requires investigation, but the question asks for what doesn't indicate "significant hematuria" when other options are clearly significant. The nuance here is that while 3-100 RBC/hpf can be significant, the specific wording of "except" suggests that among the choices, this range, even on multiple occasions, might be less immediately alarming than gross hematuria or extremely high RBC counts on a single occasion, which often trigger more urgent workups. However, in many clinical guidelines, microscopic hematuria (defined as >= 3 RBC/hpf) is considered significant, especially if persistent.
  • • "Significant hematuria"

He however gives history of low-grade fever, loss of appetite and weight loss over the past 6 months. Laboratory tests revealed a normal Creatinine levels with low C3 levels. Renal biopsy was done and IF staining for C3 revealed the following. What is diagnosis?

Following statements are true regarding the 2019 updated guidelines for SLE diagnosis

options.label: A
options.text: ANA positivity is mandatory for diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Fever is not a part of diagnostic guidelines

options.label: C
options.text: Direct Coomb’s test maybe used for diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: A. ANA positivity is mandatory for diagnosis

questions.text: Match the diseases with corresponding findings

A 74-year-old female presented with sudden onset pain and swelling in the left knee. On examination she is afebrile. X-ray shows chondrocalcinosis. Microscopic analysis of the synovial fluid is most likely to show:

options.label: C
options.text: Rhomboidal, weakly positive birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Needle shaped, strongly negative birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy

questions.correct_answer: C. Rhomboidal, weakly positive birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy

questions.text: 35 years old male comes with cough associated with haemoptysis. He also noticed passing blood in the urine. He has a purpuric skin rash over the lower limbs. Ocular examination reveals pan-uveitis and he also has conductive deafness due to serous otitis media. Anti-PR3 was positive. What is the diagnosis?

A 34 years old male brought to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. X-ray shows no evidence of gas under diaphragm. Patient has history of passing blood in the urine a month ago. Urine analysis had revealed eumorphic RBC 200/hpf with no casts. He has a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon and asymmetrical neuropathy. What is the probable diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common cause of asymmetrical neuropathy

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. A right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A 38 year old female patient with facial and ocular weakness has just been diagnosed with MG.You intend to initiate therapy with anticholinesterase medications and glucocorticoids .All of the following tests are necessary before instituting this therapy except:-

options.label: A
options.text: Evidence of old pulmonary lesions or a mammillary pattern is found on chest radiography.

options.label: B
options.text: Culture of CSF is diagnostic in majority of cases and remains gold standard.

options.label: C
options.text: It is seen most often in young children but also develops in adults.

options.label: D
options.text: CSF reveals a low leucocyte count .

questions.correct_answer: D. CSF reveals a low leucocyte count .

questions.text: On MRI of the pituitary which of the following findings is abnormal in adult ?

options.label: B
options.text: Brighter T1 intensity of the posterior pituitary.

questions.correct_answer: C. Tissue which is lower intensity than the nearby brain tissue on T1 images enhance on T2 images
